PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WILSON CLUB FORMED

INDOOR TRACK SEASON OVER

TEAMS ROUNDING INTO FORM

THE DEBATE ARRANGEMENTS

J. H. U. Enthusiasts Invade the Ancient
City in Behalf of Their
Favorite Son.

Hopkins Athletes Win Nineteen Medals
in Three Big Meets- Prospects
Bright for Rest of Year.

Homewood Soon to See Big Events—
Baseball, Lacrosse and Track
Men Making Preparations.

Judges of Adams Contest and Interclass
Debate Selected —Winning Class
Will Receive Trophy.

Last Thursday, about tw entyseven Hopkins men went down to
Annapolis, on a special car, to hear
Governor Woodrow Wilson speak
to the Legislature on the Initiative
and Referendum. The party was
e?mprised of undergraduates, alumni, University of Maryland law-stuilent men, and several PrincetonTans. Immediately on arriving, the
'party proceeded to the gubernatorial mansion, where three long hullabaloos were given for Governor
Goldsborough and Governor -Wilson. The two Governors immediately appeared and thanked the students for their enthusiasm, shaking
hands with everyone. It was
learned that seats were in such demand that the crowd would have
to go to the House at six-thirty in
order to get seats.
Everyone started out to hunt a
hasty supper at the various downtown (we didn't known there was
any "up" town) restaurants and
hotels. Their hunger appeakd, the
Young politicians hastened to the
House, where, after two hours interminable waiting, Speaker Trippe,
a Hopkins alumnus, called the
House to order. A few minutes
later the Senate was called in, followed by Governors Wilson and
Goldsborough, who received a tremendous ovation. When Governor
Wilson started to speak, those present realized that their two hours'
wait was to be fully compensated.
Governor Wilson spoke of the
dissatisfaction of the American
voter, the tariff, Initiative and RefFrendum and recall of judges, stat!rig very clearly and precisely his
ideas on these various subjects. He
Pointed out that the machine must
be beaten in the primary. It was
the selection and not the election
of candidates that counted. The
Governor stood for organization,
but not for the machine. Even
the members of the party who had
gone down to Annapolis favoring
Mr. Roosevelt, could not refrain
from applauding heartily. Through
the entire speech—not a word of
Which was lost—he explained his
Points forcibly by the use of concrete examples. To those who had
'lever heard him speak before, the
Carrying power of his voice was
remarkable. Even people in the
galleries could hear the Governor
distinctly.
Among those who made the trip
were: Wethered Barroll, George
Gillet, Edmund Donoho, Lindsay
(Continued on page 5, col. 2.)

The Hopkins track team has just
completed a most successful indoor
season, and prospects are very
bright for an even more successful outdoor-season. Coach Kocher
will allow most of the members
of the track squad to rest for
several weeks, and then they will
0-et down to hard work again in
preparation for the dual meet with
Swarthmore on April 20 at Homewood.
In the George Washington games,
held on the tenth of last month at
Convention Hall, Washington, Hopkins finished second in the, contest
for the point trophy. The Black
and Blue squad scored 17 points
in this meet. Liebensperger cap
tured first place in the high jump.
Tappan was third in third event and
second in the pole vault. Lee and
Reeside finished second in the one
and two mile runs, respectively.
Dignan landed third in the shot-put,
and Catlin crossed the line third in
the half mile. Uhler won third
place in the 600-yard novice run,
but this event did not count in the
scoring.
The Hopkins-Fifth Regiment meet
came off the following Saturday
at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Freddie Lee set a new South Atlantic resident record for one mile
of 4 minutes, 303's seconds. Dignan .again secured third place in
the shot-put, and Gil Horrax won
the bronze-medal position in the
Too-yard hurdles and the high
jump.
Much to the surprise of Georgetown and Virginia, Hopkins made
an exceptionally strong showing in
the annual Georgetown games, beating out Virginia and Georgetown
for the point trophy. The Hopkins team won 19 points in this
meet. Georgetown was- awarded
23 points, but 8 of them were scored
in the collegiate 50-yard dash which
many persons think should not have
counted for the point trophy. In
this set of games Dignan won the
shot-put. Lee ran another phenomenal race, and gave John Paul
Jones, the world's champion, the
hardest fight he has had for many
a day. Catlin was second in the
half mile, Uhler second in the
quarter mile, and Horrax second
in the open 50-vard hurdles. Tappan placed third in the high jump
and pole vault. Horrax also won
second place in the so-yard invitation hurdle race, but this event did
not count in the point scoring.

Captain Pieper and Coach I TarIan are getting their men in trim
for the gruelling games which are
soon to be played. The first is on
March 30, with' Catholic University, at Washington. Only five
days after this comes the game
with Princeton, on April 4, when,
alack! most of the fellows will
have the terrifying Easter "exams."
Captain Gail -is rapidly rounding
his team into shape. The attack
which has been weak is showing
()pod form. The team is now holding three practices a week, as it has
been delayed in getting outside.
Next Saturday will probably see
many of the bug-catchers out at
Homewood, endeavoring to capture
a place on the championship-to-be
lacrosse team. March 30 is the day
for the alumni game in which the
verdant and presuming youngsters
will get up a against the hoaryheaded veterans.
The all-star track team enjoyed a
well-deserved rest last week. One
of our .famous short-distance men
was even seen puffing on an inlaid
cigarette holder—a cigarette naturally inside. This week practice
will begin again to get the fellows
in trim for the University of Pennsylvania carnival to be held on
April 27. A handicap meet closed
to Hopkins will be held at Homewood the Saturday before; a large
amateur turn-out is hoped for.

The fifteenth annual Interclass
1)ebate and Contest in Public Speaking will be held in McCoy Hall
next Friday night. The contest in
public speaking will be participated
in by three members of the sophomore class, Messrs. Chenoweth,
Nachlas, and White, and the win—
ner will receive the Adams Medal.
The debate will be between the
junior team and the senior team,
and the winning class will receive
the Adams Trophy. The subject
of the debate is " Resolved, That
\II Corporations Engaged in InterState Trade Shall be Controlled By.
a Federal Commission." The juniors will support the affirmative, the
seniors the negative.
Mr. Ellis Miller, '12, chairman
of the General Committee on Arrangements, announces that the following gentlemen have consented
to act as judges:
Judges of the Public Speaking
Contest—Dr. John Roach Straton,
pastor of Seventh Baptist Church;
Dr. M. L. Raney, Ph.D., '04, University librarian; Mr. Lynn R.
Meekins, managing editor of the
Star.
Judges of the Debate—Randolph
Barton, Esq.; George Dobbin Penniman, A. B. '84; Dr. J. Wallace
Bryan, A. B. '02, Ph.D. 'o8. .
The University has indeed been
fortunate in securing the services
of these gentlemen. All of them
are among the most prominent
members of their respective professions, and Dr. Straton is himself
a speaker of unusual ability. Mr.
arton,, and Mr. Penniman have
had long experience in dealing with
just such problems as that which
the subject of the debate involves,
while Dr. Bryan is one of the most
promising of our younger lawyers.
They will make splendid judges.
The outcome of the debate cannot be predicted with certainty.
Although the juniors seem to have
the better of the question, still,
when it is remembered that two
members of the senior team have
had three years of experience, and
that after -five years'in both interclass and intercollegiate contests,
no affirmative team has ever carried
off the victory, it is extremely
doubtful if'they will be successful.
The negative, in the very nature of
things, enjoys a tremendous strategic i- osition, which combined with
the abilities of the senior team, is
almost certain to overwhelm their.
opponents.

(Continued on pag-e 6, col. 2.)

Interclass Debate.

All alumni and students (graduate and undergraduate) desiring
tickets for the Interclass Debate on
-March 15, address applications to
any of the following members of
the Invitation Committee:
J. J. Cornet, Jr., '12, chairman;
J. E. Richardson, 'is; A. K. Barton, 'i4; T. F. Troxall, 15.
After considerable deliberation,
the sophomores have decided not
to postpone the election of the 1914
Hullabaloo Board. Accordingly, a
meeting will be held on Tuesday,
March 12, at one o'clock, in Room
T T. President Hollyday has several
plans under consideration for forming a business department that will
really get the book out.
One thousand men recently signed
a pledge to abstain from the use
of intoxicating liquors at Notre
Dame.

Professor Shorey Lectures.
Those of us who have not attended the first three lectures of
Professor Shorey on the "Turnbull
Foundation," on account of the inclemency of the weather, and th&
erudite subjects, have missed three
of the most delightful lectures delivered at Hopkins in recent years.
In the first lecture Professor Shorey
dealt with the nature • of the epigram and gave a history of Greek
epigrammatists to Simonides. The
second lecture centered about Plato
and Meteager. The third lecture
dealt with the Roman and Byzantine Epigram. The audience was
especially delighted with Professor
Shorey's original translations of the
epigrams, some of which were exceedingly beautiful and others very
pointed and witty.

Coming Lectures.

Mr. Ball announced last week
three lectures that have been arranged to take place in the near
future. Professor Harry L. \Vilson will give an illustrated lecture
on "Ancient Cities of Etruria and
Their Buried Treasure" in McCoy
Hall, on Monday, March 18, at five
o'clock. The meeting will be under
the auspices of the Baltimore Institute of the Archeological Society
of America, of which Dr. Wilson
is one of the vice-presidents. On
the twenty-second of this month,
Rev. John F. Quirk, S. J., of
Georgetown University, and onetime head of Loyola, will give a
lecture on "Prudentius the Christian Poet." The lecture will take
place at five o'clock in McCoy Hall.
The third lecturer announced at
this time is Dr. Caspar Rene, Ph.D.,
D.D., LL.D., professor of theology
in the University of Leipzig. Professor Rene will give two 1ectures
in the Donovan Room, Tuesday and
Wednesday, March 26 and 27, at
five o'clock P. M. His topics are:
. First—"The Apocalypse and the
Canon of the New Testament."
Second—"Modern Social Movements in Germany."
President Remsen in the South.

President Remsen left Friday
night for Atlanta, Ga. Saturday
afternoon he was the guest of the
University Club of Atlanta, which
held a reception ill his honor to
which all the club members and
Hopkins men as well as the faculties of the University of Georgia
and the Georgia School of Technology were invited. Saturday he
was the guest of honor and principal speaker at the first annual banquet of the Johns Hopkins Alumni
Association of Georgia. Today he
will deliver an address before the
students and faculty of the Georgia
School of Technology, and tomorrow will go to Athens to speak
before the University of Georgia.

THE NEWS E3c0LET7ER
VOL. XVI, NO. 20.

BALTIMORE, MD., .1ARCII

11, 1912.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WILSON CLUB FORMED

INDOOR TRACK SEASON OVER

TEAMS ROUNDING INTO FORM

THE DEBATE ARRANGEMENTS

J. H. U. Enthusiasts Invade the Ancient
City in Behalf of Their
Favorite Son.

Hopkins Athletes Win Nineteen Medals
in Three Big Meets- Prospects
Bright for Rest of Year.

Homewood Soon to See Big Events—
Baseball, Lacrosse and Track
Men Making Preparations.

Judges of Adams Contest and Interclass
Debate Selected —Winning Class
Will Receive Trophy.

Last Thursday, about tw entyseven Hopkins men went down to
Annapolis, on a special car, to hear
Governor Woodrow Wilson speak
to the Legislature on the Initiative
and Referendum. The party was
e?mprised of undergraduates, alumni, University of Maryland law-stuilent men, and several PrincetonTans. Immediately on arriving, the
'party proceeded to the gubernatorial mansion, where three long hullabaloos were given for Governor
Goldsborough and Governor -Wilson. The two Governors immediately appeared and thanked the students for their enthusiasm, shaking
hands with everyone. It was
learned that seats were in such demand that the crowd would have
to go to the House at six-thirty in
order to get seats.
Everyone started out to hunt a
hasty supper at the various downtown (we didn't known there was
any "up" town) restaurants and
hotels. Their hunger appeakd, the
Young politicians hastened to the
House, where, after two hours interminable waiting, Speaker Trippe,
a Hopkins alumnus, called the
House to order. A few minutes
later the Senate was called in, followed by Governors Wilson and
Goldsborough, who received a tremendous ovation. When Governor
Wilson started to speak, those present realized that their two hours'
wait was to be fully compensated.
Governor Wilson spoke of the
dissatisfaction of the American
voter, the tariff, Initiative and RefFrendum and recall of judges, stat!rig very clearly and precisely his
ideas on these various subjects. He
Pointed out that the machine must
be beaten in the primary. It was
the selection and not the election
of candidates that counted. The
Governor stood for organization,
but not for the machine. Even
the members of the party who had
gone down to Annapolis favoring
Mr. Roosevelt, could not refrain
from applauding heartily. Through
the entire speech—not a word of
Which was lost—he explained his
Points forcibly by the use of concrete examples. To those who had
'lever heard him speak before, the
Carrying power of his voice was
remarkable. Even people in the
galleries could hear the Governor
distinctly.
Among those who made the trip
were: Wethered Barroll, George
Gillet, Edmund Donoho, Lindsay
(Continued on page 5, col. 2.)

The Hopkins track team has just
completed a most successful indoor
season, and prospects are very
bright for an even more successful outdoor-season. Coach Kocher
will allow most of the members
of the track squad to rest for
several weeks, and then they will
0-et down to hard work again in
preparation for the dual meet with
Swarthmore on April 20 at Homewood.
In the George Washington games,
held on the tenth of last month at
Convention Hall, Washington, Hopkins finished second in the, contest
for the point trophy. The Black
and Blue squad scored 17 points
in this meet. Liebensperger cap
tured first place in the high jump.
Tappan was third in third event and
second in the pole vault. Lee and
Reeside finished second in the one
and two mile runs, respectively.
Dignan landed third in the shot-put,
and Catlin crossed the line third in
the half mile. Uhler won third
place in the 600-yard novice run,
but this event did not count in the
scoring.
The Hopkins-Fifth Regiment meet
came off the following Saturday
at the Fifth Regiment Armory.
Freddie Lee set a new South Atlantic resident record for one mile
of 4 minutes, 303's seconds. Dignan .again secured third place in
the shot-put, and Gil Horrax won
the bronze-medal position in the
Too-yard hurdles and the high
jump.
Much to the surprise of Georgetown and Virginia, Hopkins made
an exceptionally strong showing in
the annual Georgetown games, beating out Virginia and Georgetown
for the point trophy. The Hopkins team won 19 points in this
meet. Georgetown was- awarded
23 points, but 8 of them were scored
in the collegiate 50-yard dash which
many persons think should not have
counted for the point trophy. In
this set of games Dignan won the
shot-put. Lee ran another phenomenal race, and gave John Paul
Jones, the world's champion, the
hardest fight he has had for many
a day. Catlin was second in the
half mile, Uhler second in the
quarter mile, and Horrax second
in the open 50-vard hurdles. Tappan placed third in the high jump
and pole vault. Horrax also won
second place in the so-yard invitation hurdle race, but this event did
not count in the point scoring.

Captain Pieper and Coach I TarIan are getting their men in trim
for the gruelling games which are
soon to be played. The first is on
March 30, with' Catholic University, at Washington. Only five
days after this comes the game
with Princeton, on April 4, when,
alack! most of the fellows will
have the terrifying Easter "exams."
Captain Gail -is rapidly rounding
his team into shape. The attack
which has been weak is showing
()pod form. The team is now holding three practices a week, as it has
been delayed in getting outside.
Next Saturday will probably see
many of the bug-catchers out at
Homewood, endeavoring to capture
a place on the championship-to-be
lacrosse team. March 30 is the day
for the alumni game in which the
verdant and presuming youngsters
will get up a against the hoaryheaded veterans.
The all-star track team enjoyed a
well-deserved rest last week. One
of our .famous short-distance men
was even seen puffing on an inlaid
cigarette holder—a cigarette naturally inside. This week practice
will begin again to get the fellows
in trim for the University of Pennsylvania carnival to be held on
April 27. A handicap meet closed
to Hopkins will be held at Homewood the Saturday before; a large
amateur turn-out is hoped for.

The fifteenth annual Interclass
1)ebate and Contest in Public Speaking will be held in McCoy Hall
next Friday night. The contest in
public speaking will be participated
in by three members of the sophomore class, Messrs. Chenoweth,
Nachlas, and White, and the win—
ner will receive the Adams Medal.
The debate will be between the
junior team and the senior team,
and the winning class will receive
the Adams Trophy. The subject
of the debate is " Resolved, That
\II Corporations Engaged in InterState Trade Shall be Controlled By.
a Federal Commission." The juniors will support the affirmative, the
seniors the negative.
Mr. Ellis Miller, '12, chairman
of the General Committee on Arrangements, announces that the following gentlemen have consented
to act as judges:
Judges of the Public Speaking
Contest—Dr. John Roach Straton,
pastor of Seventh Baptist Church;
Dr. M. L. Raney, Ph.D., '04, University librarian; Mr. Lynn R.
Meekins, managing editor of the
Star.
Judges of the Debate—Randolph
Barton, Esq.; George Dobbin Penniman, A. B. '84; Dr. J. Wallace
Bryan, A. B. '02, Ph.D. 'o8. .
The University has indeed been
fortunate in securing the services
of these gentlemen. All of them
are among the most prominent
members of their respective professions, and Dr. Straton is himself
a speaker of unusual ability. Mr.
arton,, and Mr. Penniman have
had long experience in dealing with
just such problems as that which
the subject of the debate involves,
while Dr. Bryan is one of the most
promising of our younger lawyers.
They will make splendid judges.
The outcome of the debate cannot be predicted with certainty.
Although the juniors seem to have
the better of the question, still,
when it is remembered that two
members of the senior team have
had three years of experience, and
that after -five years'in both interclass and intercollegiate contests,
no affirmative team has ever carried
off the victory, it is extremely
doubtful if'they will be successful.
The negative, in the very nature of
things, enjoys a tremendous strategic i- osition, which combined with
the abilities of the senior team, is
almost certain to overwhelm their.
opponents.

(Continued on pag-e 6, col. 2.)

Interclass Debate.

All alumni and students (graduate and undergraduate) desiring
tickets for the Interclass Debate on
-March 15, address applications to
any of the following members of
the Invitation Committee:
J. J. Cornet, Jr., '12, chairman;
J. E. Richardson, 'is; A. K. Barton, 'i4; T. F. Troxall, 15.

Professor Shorey Lectures.
Those of us who have not attended the first three lectures of
Professor Shorey on the "Turnbull
Foundation," on account of the inclemency of the weather, and th&
erudite subjects, have missed three
of the most delightful lectures delivered at Hopkins in recent years.
In the first lecture Professor Shorey
dealt with the nature • of the epigram and gave a history of Greek
epigrammatists to Simonides. The
second lecture centered about Plato
and Meteager. The third lecture
dealt with the Roman and Byzantine Epigram. The audience was
especially delighted with Professor
Shorey's original translations of the
epigrams, some of which were exceedingly beautiful and others very
pointed and witty.

Coming Lectures.

Mr. Ball announced last week
three lectures that have been arranged to take place in the near
future. Professor Harry L. \Vilson will give an illustrated lecture
on "Ancient Cities of Etruria and
Their Buried Treasure" in McCoy
Hall, on Monday, March 18, at five
o'clock. The meeting will be under
the auspices of the Baltimore Institute of the Archeological Society
of America, of which Dr. Wilson
is one of the vice-presidents. On
the twenty-second of this month,
Rev. John F. Quirk, S. J., of
Georgetown University, and onetime head of Loyola, will give a
lecture on "Prudentius the Christian Poet." The lecture will take
place at five o'clock in McCoy Hall.
The third lecturer announced at
this time is Dr. Caspar Rene, Ph.D.,
D.D., LL.D., professor of theology
in the University of Leipzig. Professor Rene will give two 1ectures
in the Donovan Room, Tuesday and
Wednesday, March 26 and 27, at
five o'clock P. M. His topics are:
. First—"The Apocalypse and the
Canon of the New Testament."
Second—"Modern Social Movements in Germany."
President Remsen in the South.

President Remsen left Friday
night for Atlanta, Ga. Saturday
afternoon he was the guest of the
University Club of Atlanta, which
held a reception ill his honor to
which all the club members and
Hopkins men as well as the faculties of the University of Georgia
and the Georgia School of Technology were invited. Saturday he
was the guest of honor and principal speaker at the first annual banquet of the Johns Hopkins Alumni
Association of Georgia. Today he
will deliver an address before the
students and faculty of the Georgia
School of Technology, and tomorrow will go to Athens to speak
before the University of Georgia.
